prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
Although surrounded by weak extended emission (see Fig. 4), our actual science target (Sgr A* itself) is a point source for all configurations of ALMA in all spectral bands. Estimates of the flux density per beam have been taken from Brinkerink & Falcke (2013), from ALMA measurements. Linear polarization degree estimates of the source have been obtained from our own measurements from the IRAM 30m Telescope (see Fig. 2 on the Scientific Justification [SJ]). Note that the desired sensitivity per pointing has been set artificially to the limit that allows the OT the maximum possible integration time on source within the 3 mandatory observing hours of any polarimetric Science Goal (SG). There is only a practical justification for that, i.e. to spend as much of such 3h allocated to the SG on the target source. Although it is not the main scientific driver of this proposal, this will also allow us to study variability of the target source on time scales of hours, on which the Sgr A* is well known to be able to vary by factors of 2 or larger.
Our scientific objective on every one of the visits is to compute the linear polarization properties of the compact (point) source Sgr A*, and disentangle it from those of its surroundings. In particular, to be able to do that with the limitations for polarization imaging in Cycle 2, we request to observe on extended ALMA configurations (and without employing multi-configuration combinations) to resolve-out the extended structure around Sgr A* with angular sizes larger that 1/3 of the primary beam at every observing band. Our selection of the desired angular resolution is specifically based on that requirement. In particular, our ALMA array simulations demonstrate that for configuration 6 or more extended, ALMA (in single configuration) resolves out such extended emission.
It is extremely important to our science objectives that, for every visit proposed here, the parallel observations in both science goals (for Bands 3 and 6) are performed consecutively (i.e. with the minimum possible time spacing between them). This is extremely critical since the polarization properties of the source are well known to change on time scales of several hours, and our objective is to combine the measurements from Bands 3 and 6 as if they were observed simultaneously (see an example on Fig. 3-Left of the SJ). The first visit should be observed as soon as possible in Cycle 2 to avoid missing the current period of activity of the source that has motivated this proposal (see Fig. 3-Right of the SJ).
For current Band 3 and 6 ALMA setups, the change of the polarization angle (chi) with wavelength is related to the rotation measure RM as Delta_chi=RM (lambda_2^2-lambda_1^2), where lambda_1 and lambda_2 are two observing wavelengths from where the rotation measure needs to be measured. For conservatively low RM~-5x10^4 rad/m^2 (see Fig. 3 of the SJ), Delta_chi turns out to be ~20 deg. between Bands 3 and 6. This polarization angle differences are measured well above uncertainties within the standard 3 observing hours per SG of ALMA in full polarization mode (~6 deg. for polarization angle). Even if much lower RM happens during one of our ALMA observations (on which an upper limit to that RM measurement will still provide useful information about the minimum accretion rates in operation at Sgr A*), the strong RM variations detected by us (by Delta_RM>10^5 rad/m^2 in time scales of 1-2 weeks) will allow to detect the RM variability we are looking for.
In Band 3, the low degree of polarization of Sgr A* (~1%) makes the experiment more difficult, but the Faraday rotation effect is a factor of ~7 stronger than at Band 6 (note again the lambda^2 dependence of Delta_chi), hence compensating the difficulties to measure accurately the polarization angle at 3mm, and allowing to measure fit polarization angle changes between the Band 3 sub-bands for such low |RM|=10^5 rad/m^2 (see above).

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: We currently face a unique opportunity to witness, in our immediate cosmic vicinity, the direct interaction of the G2 gas cloud with the accretion flow onto the black hole in Sgr A*. Through an ongoing 3 and 1mm polarization monitoring at the IRAM 30m Telescope, we have detected a series of rapid (1-2 week) variations of the Faraday rotation. These variations are a direct prove of strong and rapid changes of the properties of Sgr A*'s accretion flow, and could well be related to the material from G2. No total flux flare of the encounter is evident from our data, or data at other spectral ranges. Hence, millimeter polarization might be the only current window to discern the G2 cloud. We propose to observe Sgr A* in polarization mode in Bands 3 and 6, with ALMA configuration 6 or 7, on 3 visits separated by 1-2 weeks. This will allow us to confirm the strong and fast Faraday-rotation variability found on our previous observations, and to disentangle the polarized emission coming from Sgr A* and the spurious one from adjacent regions in the 30m’s beam. Our new ALMA data will provide the needed information to perform a firm computation of Sgr A*'s accretion rate (and of its changes).
